Expectation1: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation1: A critical call reports a multi-vehicle collision on a highway outside the city.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story:
The radio crackled with urgency—there’d been a multi-vehicle collision on the highway, and I was the closest ambulance driver. My heart pounded as I grabbed the keys, knowing every second mattered. As I rushed toward the door, Brother Yusuf caught my arm. “Imam, do you have a moment? I’ve been struggling and could really use your advice.” His eyes pleaded for comfort, and I remembered his quiet mention after Friday prayers that he needed guidance. 

But the dispatcher’s voice echoed in my ear, reminding me of the lives hanging in the balance. As an ambulance driver, I was expected to respond instantly, to be the difference between life and death. As an imam, I was expected to be present, to listen, to offer solace when my community needed me. I felt torn, the weight of both uniforms pressing on my shoulders. My mind raced, guilt and duty wrestling inside me, as I stood frozen between the call of the siren and the call of the heart.
